title: What happened when this phone addict went on holiday for the first time without one
text:
'Without my phone I am disorientated, late, alienated, under-informed and bored - or so I thought'

Ever since I got my first Nokia 5100 at the age of 12, I have had an unhealthy attachment to my phone; which made less sense back then given that I have never liked voice calls, making or receiving, and that calling people was really the only thing the Nokia was capable of doing. Still it was never far from my side, like a mini homing device, its beeps and buttons tickling my neurons into a lifelong reliance.

I say this is unhealthy more out of habit, because we are told it is, but in truth I don’t buy into that scaremongering. My life, as far as I’m concerned, has only ever been enriched by my phone - more so as the devices have got wizzier. These days, my deeply cherished iPhone is a 226-gram atlas, encyclopedia, calendar, wallet, rolodex, camera and clock. It is a satellite link to the rest of the world. It makes it safer and easier to travel alone. It is how I stay so close to the members of my family stationed in foreign lands. Podcasts feed my curiosities, and make my commute interesting rather than monotonous.
